Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Early EEOC, Legal Mobilization, and the New Administrative State

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Summary

This project analyzes the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission's (EEOC) early history in order to advance understanding of legal mobilization and state capacity. The study examines the EEOC's ability to implement its objectives without formal authority and the role of non-state actors in the implementation of employment discrimination law, which would in turn inform how understaffed government agencies can successfully shape legal and political reform and how legal mobilization can be a tool of state capacity building. The PI does this through a multi-site comparative design that creates the first district court-level database of early EEOC litigation efforts.

Technical Summary

The PI analyzes the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission's (EEOC) early history in order to advance understanding of legal mobilization and state capacity. The PI contributes to three sets of scholarly literature: (1) Administrative Law and State Capacity; (2) Legal Mobilization; and (3) Labor Law, Politics and the History of the EEOC. The study examines the EEOC's ability to implement its objectives without formal authority and the role of non-state actors in the implementation of employment discrimination law, which would in turn inform how understaffed government agencies can successfully shape legal and political reform and how legal mobilization can be a tool of state capacity building. The PI does this through a multi-site comparative design that creates the first district court-level database of early EEOC litigation efforts. The data collection process involves formal interviews, archival research, and survey research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tania Melo has completed research for her dissertation “ ‘We’re Not Breaking the Law. We Are Exercising Our Citizen’s Right to Enforce It’: Social Movements and the Mobilizing of Private Citizens as Law Enforcement” supported by the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant. During her funding period, Tania visited National Archives in Seattle, Chicago, Washington D.C., and College Park. Further, she interviewed civic, legal, and government actors, as well as conducted research in private and public organizations’ archives.

As a socio-legal scholar, Melo is interested in understanding the dynamic interaction between law, politics, and society as it relates to the evolving role of government regulatory agencies and societal groups in transforming the administrative state. With the support of the NSF, she undertook a historical analysis of the dynamic interaction between government agencies and civil rights organizations in expanding state capacity.

In the process of accomplishing the goals of her research, Melo compiled and digitized records of the legal actions of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission during the early years of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as well as documents from civil organizations' legal efforts.

Melo's research at the archives, interviews, and historical analyses form the basis of her dissertation. To be completed in 2018, the dissertation is an important contribution to the fields of Law, Political Science, and Sociology as it integrates legal tactics into the social movement literature on political opportunities; and integrates social movements into the socio-legal literature on the role of courts and state capacity.
